Comment: I have been experimenting with the English opening against the computer lately to get a feel for how it plays.
This is the particular branch that I am seeking for my experiments, the symmetrical version. Both players stake out control of a d file square on the opponents side of the board.
With this move white plays against ...e5.
Black follows with a similar plan.
This move fights for d4, and guards c4, and activates the bishop so it can be developed in preperation for 0-0, and is meant to support the followup move of d2-d4.
Black begins an immediate fight for d5, fully developing a second pawn in the fight for the center.
Exchanging this pawn away makes sense so that black has less influence in the center, and to prevent suffocating pawn moves by black.
Material equality is maintained, but the knight will not be welcomed here by white.

This is a great developing move for the bishop, it is the most active placement. There is no real threat against the knight without a second piece, but the move does influence the center and draws a line to f7.
This move is not really necessary because the queen has guard of the knight, but it does allow black to try a tactic of ...Nc3! where it attacks both queen and the loose bishop.
This refutes the tactical idea.
Black repositions the bishop to take control of c2, d3, e4 squares, but this position begs a fork.
+/= Threatening an e3-e4 fork.
?! Black chooses a rather dramatic, yet clumsy method to refute the fork by way of a distracting check, but this too has a tactical refutation.
! Now there are 3 threats for black to counter.
Black finds a way out of the traps, but the knight is not in the happiest of positions here due to the pin that it has jumped into.
+/- This prevents any wild ideas of ...Nxd3+, and it gives white a serious lead in development.
Black seeks to catch up in development.
!? Creating a future threat once the rook is guarded.
Black finally gains king safety, somewhat, and brings the rook into a coordinated attack with the bishop on d3.
